traordinary—I can't say that the hole in the corner is uncommon, it may not be—it is the diaper the child had on—I have been four years a nurse at Isleworth—I never saw a diaper like this—I have certainly seen diapers with holes where the safety pin goes; it is not usual to pin them in the corner like this—I was examined twice before the Magistrate; I don't recollect saying that I only saw the articles once—I don't think I did—my deposition was read over, and I signed it—I am quite sure the child was a healthy child—it did not refuse the breast—she was not nursing other children to my knowledge—I never saw her do it—I could not always be in one ward; there are a hundred patients to see to—I am the only person here from the infirmary—she might have nursed other children without my knowing it.

MARY EDWARDS . I keep the White Horse Inn at Norbiton; that is about 10 minutes' walk from the Kingston Union Infirmary—on a Wednesday morning in the beginning of July, between 10 and 11 o'clock, the prisoner came into the house with a baby—she had a glass of beer—my niece called my attention to the child, because it was a fine baby, and I went into the tap-room where she was sitting, and looked at it; it was a very fine baby—she said she had come from the infirmary, and she had to wait till 4 o'clock to

register the baby—she said it was born with a caul over its head—she left and afterwards returned, and said she had been to register the baby and back to the infirmary to take the register—she said the nurse would not allow her to have the caul, and I told her to ask Mr. Clark at the union—she left just before 4 o'clock, and said she was going to Weybridge, to her mother's—she did not mention her name or say anything more about herself—I gave her some tea and something to eat; I did not give her any money—I saw no more of her—it was a very nice baby, and appeared to be all right.

Cross-examined. She seemed very fond of it—I know nothing of the bodies of several children being found in the neighbourhood lately—nothing was said to me about her nursing other children in the workhouse.

JOHN HARRIS . I live at No. 2, Richmond Villas, Kingston-on-Thames—I am registrar of births and deaths for the Kingston sub-district—on 2nd July I registered the birth of a male child, by a person who gave the name of Alice Ward—the name was put down as "Frederick," the date of the birth 4th June, and the address "Oatlands Park, "Weybridge"—my place is about 100 yards from the White Horse.

JAMES LANGRIDGB . I am a pork butcher, of 23, Garden Row, Mort
lake—on Friday afternoon, 18th July, about 2.30,1 was walking along the Lower Mortlake Road, and saw the body of a child in a ditch; I was on the pathway, and I crossed the road to look at some mowers in a field, and on looking in the ditch saw the body of the child; there was water in the ditch, and the back part of the head was partly out of the water—I called the attention of the mowers to the child, and then went and fetched a policeman—I saw him take the child out of the ditch—there were some articles of clothing on it—I saw them taken off afterwards; there was a flannel band and a diaper; that was all I saw.

JAMES WARNE (Policeman V 261). On Friday, 18th July, in conse
quence of information from Mr. Langridge, I went with him to the Lower Mortlake Road, and there saw the dead body of a male child in a ditch—I conveyed it to the mortuary at Mortlake, and a doctor was afterwards called and the child was undressed—this belly-band and diaper are what it was wealing—there were no other articles upon the child.
Cross-examined. I did not search the house of the prisoner's mother.

SAMUEL SAMPSON (Police Sergeant, Scotland Yard). On 19th July I received instructions to make inquiries about this child, and on the evening of the 24th I saw the prisoner at her father's house, at West End, Mortlake—that is between 300 and 400 yards from the ditch where the child was found—I told her I was a detective sergeant, and from information I had received I believed she had recently been confined of a child—she said she had—I asked her where the child was—she said "My child is all right"—I said "But where is your child?"—she again said "My child is all right"—I asked her the third time, and she repeated again "My child is all right and at Weybridge"—I said "Who has charge of your child at Weybridge?" she made no answer—I said "You refuse to give me any further account of your child any more than it is all right at Weybridge?" she said "Yes"—I asked where she was confined; she said at the Kingston Union—I asked in what name; she said "Alice Ward"—I then left to make further inquiries—I did not search the house—I went to Weybridge and endeavoured to trace the child, but failed to do so—on 4th August I went to the house again with Inspector Shaw and saw the prisoner at the door

—he told her who we were and that we had come to make inquiries respecting her child, and he said "Where is your child?"—she then asked us to come inside, and she led us through the passage into the kitchen—as loon as we got into the kitchen a man came in who said he was a solicitor, and he told the prisoner not to answer any questions or say anything—I requested him to go away but he would not, and as he annoyed us I went out to see if I could find an officer in uniform, so I did not hear anything farther—I left Inspector Shaw there—afterwards at the railway station at Mortlake the prisoner said "Is there a man named Pink in trouble?"—I said "No"—she said "He ought to be; he is the father of my child; I should have summoned him only I hare sworn one child already, and they asked so many funny questions I did not like to do so"—her mother lived at this house as well as her father—I know that they have lived there over 12 months—no articles of clothing were found there—the frock and petti
coat said to have left the workhouse have never been traced.

Cross-examined. I did not hear Inspector Shaw caution her that what she said would be used in evidence against her—I believe there have been two bodies of children found besides this one; not in the exact neighbour
hood, some distance off, one at Barnes and one at Kew; that would be a distance of about a mile or a mile and a half—I know the ditch in question—I believe it is not a tidal ditch; the water runs one way, but not very strongly.

Re-examined. It is a continual steady flow, not sufficient to move any
thing the size of this child—I cannot tell where the other bodies were found—I had nothing to do with those cases.

EDWARD SHAW (Police Inspector). On 4th August, between 1 and 2 in the afternoon, I went with Sampson to the residence of the prisoner's father at Mortlake—I knocked at the door, the prisoner answered it—I asked her her name—she said, "Charlotte Cutler"—I told her who I was—I was in plain clothes—I said I wished to speak to her—she said, "Come outside"—I said, "No, I would rather see you iuside the house—she took me into the back part of the house; there was a young woman there—I then asked the prisoner if she could tell me where her child was that she had been confined of—she said, "My child is all right"—I said, "Where?"—at this time I was interrupted by a gentleman who came into the wash-house and said he was a solicitor—I told him not to interrupt me in the execution of my duty—he got out a piece of paper and a pencil, and told the prisoner not to say anything—I then spoke to her again about the child—she said, "If my sister goes out I will tell you"—the sister went out and the gentleman also—the prisoner then said, "I will tell you now all about it; I left Kingston Union on the 2nd or 3rd of last month, I went into a public-house and had some refreshment; I took the train to Kingston, at St. Margaret's I got out and I walked to Mortlake, and while I was on the bridge I met a woman with a child, and I gave her a shilling to take the child away"—she said she did not want to disgrace her family by taking the child home—she did not at that time say where the woman was to take the child—I told her I should take her into custody on suspi
cion of having murdered her child—I then conveyed her to the railway station at Mortlake, and while standing on the platform she said, "There has been three or four children found lately, has there not?"—I said, "Yes"—I then conveyed her to Richmond police-station—I afterwards heard her
make a further statement, which Inspector Fairy took down in writing the same day.

Cross-examined. The gentleman I speak of is sitting in Court, I did not know him—he did not ask what I was doing there—I was in plair clothing—I told him three or four times that I was an officer of police, but I could not convince him—he asked to see my card; I showed it to tin—he told the prisoner not to answer any questions—I did not caution her in any way, or tell her that what she said might be used in evidence against her.
Re-examined. I was making inquiries.

DAVID FAIRY (Police Inspector V). On 4th August the prisoner was brought to the Richmond station by Inspector Shaw on suspicion of murder ing her child—I said, "You are not called upon to say anything before 1 read the charge, but should you say anything, what you say will be taken down in writing, and used as evidence against you"—she burst into tears, and then made this statement, which I wrote down—(Read:) "I only wish to say that I did not murder my child, and I was in hopes he was alive; I gave him to a person on the bridge near the gas factory, and I asked her if she would take it to the Richmond Union for me, and I gave her a shilling, that was all the money I was possessed of, and she promised me faithfully she would take it the next morning."

BENJAMIN BILLING . I am porter at the Richmond Union "Workhouse—I keep the book of children admitted to the workhouse—there was no child left at the workhouse without the mother about this time in July—one child was admitted in July; the mother is now in the Asylum and the father took the child away.

ROBERT COCHRANE MULLINS . I am a registered medical practitioner—on 18th July last I was living at Mortlake, and was assistant to Dr. Mar
shall there—the constable Warne came to me, and in consequence of what he said I went to the mortuary at Mortlake, and there saw the dead body of a male child—I could not recognise the features; the body was in a state of putridity—I could not form any positive opinion as to how long it had been dead; I should say probably about fourteen days; it might possibly have been more; I don't think lesss; it might be—the atmosphere might have a certain degree of influence—there were no marks that I could trace; from the appearance of the body I should not be able to state whether there were any marks of violenoe; I found none—it was a well-developed child—I could not form any opinion as to the cause of death; it was quite impossible to do so; from the state of the body I could form no judgment whether it had died from natural causes or any other—it was difficult to give an opinion as to its age; I did form an opinion that it was between 3 and 6 months old, probably 4; that was not a positive opinion—I came to that conclusion from the structural development—it was impossible to give an opinion as to whether it might only have been 2 or 3 weeks old; one child at 3 or four weeks old may be quite as well developed and as large as one of 2 or 3 months; we meet with such cases every day; it is quite possible that this child may have been born at the beginning of June; my impres
sion was the contrary; it is not probable, it is highly improbable—I could not trace any marks of vaccination; it was impossible to do so, it was a putrid body.
Cross-examined. The average length of a child a month old is somewhat

about 18 inches—the length of this child was 23 1/2; that would he an exceptional length for a child a month old; we hear of monstrosities—decomposition frequently causes a body to contract—this body was con
tracted—my opinion was that this child was probably 4 and possibly 6 months old; at the same time, from the state of the body, I should not give a definite opinion regarding it—I fix the minimum at 3 and the maximum at 6—my judgment is founded partially on the length of the child and the structural development of the limbs—in the first few months the signs of structural development are pretty well denoted—it is very easy for a medical man to judge of the age of a child by the structural develop
ment.
Re-examined. I have been in practice nearly seven years—my knowledge of children arises from what I have seen in practice and from my general knowledge in studying medicine.

LUCY WHITEBREAD (Re-examined). I have been nurse at the Kingston Union Infirmary since 17th February—I have had sixteen children born there—at the time this inquiry was going on I had a child there a month old.

p.hi: proposed to ask the length of that child.
expressing a doubt of its admissibility it teas not pressed.
then submitted that there was realty no case to go to the Jury, the identification of the body being almost disproved by ike evidence of the surgeon.
relied Upon the contradictory state, mehts of the prisoner and the identification of the two articles of clothing found upon the body of the child.
considered that there was some evidence upon which to take the opinion of the Jury.

div1.p: MARY CUTLER . I am the prisoner's mother—I Sent to her in the Work-house a set of clothes for the child of which she was confined; a frock, long petticoat, two woollen shawls, a belly band, a shirt and flannel—I knew that she was, in consequence of her poverty, going to be confined in the union—the belly band I sent her was not hemmed or herring-boned—I never used such a thing—the one I sent was exactly similar to this clean one (producing it)—I had many of them in use—I am prepared to swear that they were neither hemmed or herring-boned.

Cross-examined. I did not go to the workhouse to see the child—I have never seen it—I did not visit my daughter there—she came back to me on Wednesday evening, 2nd July, between 9 and 10—she had no child with her or any child's clothing—she said she had given it to a strange woman on the bridge by the gas factory to take to the Richmond Union; and that she gave the person a shilling—she had money when she left home—she has been to Weybridge; not since the child was born—she has never been away from home.
Re-examined. I know a man named Pink—I believe he lives in Mortlake—my daughter is a kind, good-dispositioned girl—I have got her other child at home, and have always taken care of it.

JOSEPH ROGERS , M.D., and M.R.C.S. I have been over 30 years in practice, and 23 years surgeon to the Westminster and Strand Union—I have had a large number of children under my notice at the butts and subsequently—I cannot call to mind that I have ever seen a case of a child a month old 23 1/2 inches in length—I do not say it is impossible—

decomposition so advanced, as this seems to have been, would cause diminution in the bulk—at an" earlier period it would probably cause it to be a little longer; but, as it advances, the skin breaks, and from the air that is generated in the body it gets shorter—in the state of decomposition in which this body was I think it would get shorter—I think it is open to the belief that this child was between three and six months old; it might have been three or four months old—I should question its being only a month old—I would not swear positively, but I should question it.
Cross-examined. I did not see the child—I merely infer what I have said from the account of the decomposition.
NOT GUILTY .

865.
WILLIAM NORMAN (26)
, Feloniously killing and slaying
Sarah Norman.
MR. POLAND Prosecuted; MR. VALENTINE BBOWN Defended.

WILLIAM THOMAS PAYNE . I am a fitter, and live at 44, Vauxhall Walk—the deceased, Sarah Norman, was my sister—she was 25 years of age, and was married to the prisoner, who is a coal porter at a gas factory—they were living at 3, Curry Street, Nine Elms, Battersea—they had four children—the youngest was nearly three months old at the time of the accident—I saw my sister dead on the Tuesday morning at St. Thomas' Hospital; after that I saw the prisoner; I said, "You have done a fine thing, young fellow, have you not?"—he said, "Yes, it was entirely her own fault; she aggravated me to do it"—she was a sober woman as far as I knew.
Cross-examined. The last time I saw her was two months before.

MARY ANN KILBY . I am the wife of James Kilby, a dustman, and live at 12, Ponton Street, Battersea—I knew the prisoner and his wife—on Monday evening, 25th August, I saw the deceased at her own door; she spoke to me, and went and laid her baby on the bed asleep, and I went for a walk with her round the houses; we met some friends, and had some drink—we remained out till 10 o'clock—afterwards, about 12 o'clock or half past, she was sitting on the kerb in Curry Street, near her own house; I was with her—we were sober—the prisoner came out of his house; he was dressed, and had the baby underneath his coat—he had his boots on—she said to me "Here is my baby"—he said "Sarah, here is the baby"—she said "Yes, you b——thing, keep it"—he said "So I can"—he put the child into her arms—she took it, and said "I am glad I have got my baby"—he was walking away indoors, and she halloaed after him "Go out you b——half-starved thing, you bastard," and used very foul language to him—in about 20 minutes he came out again to her—she was still sitting on the kerb—she called him names, and said "Look at your b——old wh—of a mother"—with that he walked up, buttoned his coat, and said "Let my mother rest, she is nothing to you"—she said "Yes, the b——old wh—"—he then gave her a kick somewhere about the side; he had his boots on—she fell back, and said "Oh, Bill! oh, Bill! you have done for me"—she had her baby in her arms at the time—he said nothing, but walked away—after she had laid a little while she said "Where is Bill?"—he then came to her, and cried, and took her by the head behind with a pillow, and said "Sarah, Sarah, my girl, speak to me"—she made, no reply—I saw blood underneath where she was lying—a constable came up, and a doctor was
sent for, and she was taken to the hospital in a cab—I could not tell whether the prisoner was drunk or sober.

Cross-examined. He was very fond of his wife, and a very good husband, and very patient—he came into the street twice to try to induce her to come indoors—she would not go, and he could not move her in—I did not see him come out undressed—he is a labourer—I was not drunk, nor was she—we had been two hours in a public-house with one pot of beer.

TIMOTHY DALY . I am a labourer, and live at 4, Currie Street, Nine Elms—I knew the prisoner and his wife—on Monday night I was going home, and saw Mrs. Kilby and Mrs. Norman sitting on the kerb—Mrs. Norman bad the baby—she spoke to me; I could not tell whether she was sober or not—I sat down by them—shortly afterwards the prisoner came out of his house in his night-shirt without his trousers or boots—he asked his wife whether she was coming indoors—she said "No, go away you b——thing"—she used some very bad language to him—he said nothing, but walked upstairs—in about 10 minutes he came out again dressed, and he had his boots on, and I saw him come up and give his wife a kick somewhere about the groin—I could hardly tell what sort of a kick it was—she fell back, and did not speak—afterwards she said "Bill, Bill, you have done for me"—he made no reply—I don't know what became of him—a constable came up shortly afterwards—I saw blood where the woman was lying—a doctor was sent for—I afterwards heard her say "Bill, Bill, kiss me," or "speak to me"—he had come up from round the corner—he did kiss her—she was then taken to the hospital.
Cross-examined. I did not see any one making a mockery of the prisoner when he came out in his night shirt—she used bad language to him before he gave her the kick.

JOHN GARLAND (Policeman W 383). I was on duty in Currie Street, shortly before 2 o'clock—I saw the deceased lying on the pavement, as if she had fallen back—she said, "He has done for me"—she bled very much from the lower part of her body—I raised her up, but I saw it was doing injury and I laid her down again—a doctor came and examined her and ordered her removal to the hospital, and when we arrived there in the cab she was dead—I took the prisoner into custody.

THOMAS BAKER . I am a student at Charing Cross Hospital—I live with Dr. Sutcliffe, of Battersea Park Road—on the morning of 26th August, abont 2 30, the police fetched me; I found the woman lying in Currie Street in a dying state, she was in a state of collapse—she had lost a large quantity of blood, I should think three pints—it came from the vagina—I had her put into a cab and sent to the hospital; it might have been caused by a kick.

KANIERO POKAKO . I am one of the house surgeons at St. Thomas' Hospital—on Monday night or Tuesday morning I received the deceased from the police—she was quite dead and her clothes were saturated with blood—I afterwards examined the body—the organs were healthy—there was a lacerated wound on the left side of the vagina, an inch and one-eighth in length and about an inch deep—it was such an injury as might be caused by a violent kick—she died from loss of blood arising from that injury.

p.hi: The Prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy by the JURY
on account of the provocation he received. —
Three Months' Imprisonment.

866.
TERALASCO LEONILDA (22)
, Feloniously wounding
James Miller, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.
LILLET Prosecuted; A. B. KELLY Defended.

JAMES MILLER . I am a labourer, and live in the Lower Road, Deptford—on 9th August, about 12 o'clock, I was in Napier Terrace near the Plough Road in company with my young woman's mother, Mary Ann Pressland; I had just parted with my young woman—I heard a scream at the top of the road, I ran up to see what was the matter and saw two men catching hold of Franklin's young woman, Miss Mayne, and pulling her into the road, they seemed to be foreigners; when I got up they ran away—my young woman came out of doors and the four of us went on to the bridge, that is my young woman and Franklin and his young woman—we were turning round to oome back home and we met three other men, foreigners—they caught hold of my young woman round the neck and pulled her off the path; I went up to the prisoner who was one of them, and pushed him away; he then struck me in the left hand and arm—one of his comrades made a run towards me and the prisoner struck him in the side—the man called out, "Oh John, no," or something like that, put his hand to his side and ran away over the bridge—I felt my hand numbed and my finger doubled up—I went back to Napier Terrace and my hand was bathed, blood was running down my arm, my coat was cut through—I was taken to the police surgeon about an hour after, and he dressed my wound—I first went to Dr. Kelly, of Plough Road, he would not look at my arm—I had given no provocation to the prisoner, only pushed him away—there was sufficient light to enable me to see him; I have no doubt about his being the man that struck me.

Cross-examined. I saw no knife in anybody's hands—I saw that my hand was covered with blood—I did not see a man named Adolphe there. I saw him afterwards at the police-court; I did not recognise him as one of the three foreigners; I could not say whether he was the man the prisoner struck, it was one of the two—he was coming towards me in a fighting attitude when the prisoner struck him.

MARY ANN PRESSLAND . I am single and live in Napier Terrace, Plough Road, Rotherhithe—on the night of 8th August, a little after 12 o'clock, I was in company with James Miller; he left me indoors and went up the street with my mother—I heard a man scream and ran up to the top of the street and saw five foreigners pulling Franklin's young woman in the road—Miller went up and the men ran over the bridge—Franklin's young woman ran down home with mother, and Franklin, me, and Miller went up on the bridge—we met three foreigners; the prisoner put his arms round my neck and Miller pushed him away and the prisoner pulled out his knife and stabbed him twice—I saw it glitter, I was close to him—then Adolphe, one of his friends, ran in between Miller, and he caught a blow in his side from the prisoner—I then returned with Miller to Napier Terrace; Franklin tame home too, but he did not stop indoors—Miller's arm was all open and the joints of the fingers of his left hand were cut and bleeding—his wounds were bathed—he had done nothing to the prisoner but push him away when he had his arm round my neck.

Cross-examined. Another foreigner was charged at the police-court with the prisoner; I don't know his name; he was discharged—the prisoner put his arm round my nock in a friendly way; my young man was

annoyed and interposed, then there was ft general confusion—I am sure it was a knife that I saw in the prisoner's hand—I did not know at the moment that Miller was stabbed, not till he was coming away.

GEORGE FRANKLIN . I am a labourer at Deptford—on 8th August I was in company with my young woman in Ploughbridge, Rotherhithe—I saw five foreigners come along, one or more of them interfered with my young woman, after a bit of a scuffle I ran over the bridge—while I was standing there I saw Miller and Pressland on the bridge with three foreigners, the prisoner was one of them—I did not see him do anything—I saw Miller after he had been home and come back again—I did not see anything the matter with his hand or arm—about half an hour afterwards I saw his father-in-law take him to the doctor's; he had his arm bound up.

THOMAS BANNISTER (Police Inspector R). Shortly after 1 o'clock in the morning of 9th August I saw Miller at the station—he showed me his hand and arm—there was a wound on the left arm above the elbow, and one on the back of the left hand, both bleeding—I sent for the divisional surgeon, who dressed his wounds—he gave a description of the person who had wounded him, in consequence of which I went in search of the prisoner—I met him coming along with a constable—he answered the description given—he was placed with several others in the charge room, seven or eight, some of his own countrymen, and Miller picked him out at once—he war charged with cutting and wounding Miller—I afterwards went to Plough-bridge and saw a large quantity of blood on the pavement from there down to the entrance of the docks, about 300 yards—that was not in the direction in which Miller went, but the direction in which the other Italians had gone—the prisoner had no hat on when I met him—I saw the other man who was wounded at the hospital.

Cross-examined. I found a few pieces of broken pipe on the bridge—a man named Calose was charged with being concerned in this—he was subse
quently discharged.

BENJAMIN BROWNING , M.R.C.S. I live at Rotherhithe—I am divisional surgeon to the police—on 9th August, between 1 and 2 in the morning, I was called to the Rotherhithe Police-station to examine Miller—he was. bleeding from two incised wounds, one on the left knuckle of the little finger, the other at the back of the same arm, below the shoulder—that was nearly four inches long; it was not very deep; it had exposed the muscle both wounds were bleeding very much—I dressed them—he was perfectly sober.

Cross-examined. I saw a knife afterwards at the police-court—such a knife as this (produoed) would produce the wounds, but it would also produce much more severe wounds—from such a formidable weapon as this I should expect to find more severe wounds—I never saw a foreign sailor carry such a knife as this.

CHARLES ELLIOT NASH . I am a deal porter in the Surrey Commercial Docks—I found this knife and this dagger there when I was at work on the morning of 9th August—the dagger was sticking in a deal, and the sheath was lying in another place—there were marks on the dagger the colour of blood—it appeared as if it had been thrown over the fence, which is nine or—ten feet high.
THOMAS BANNISTER (Re-examined). The fence described would be in the direction in which the men ran—a great number of foreign sailors are

employed in the ships in the docks—the prisoner was a sailor in one of those ships—I have not seen foreign sailors use a dagger similar to this; I have seen them with knives similar to this knife—I found this other knife in the prisoner's hunk on board his ship—he had not been on board since the occurrence.

GUILTY
of unlawfully wounding. —
Six Months' Imprisonment.

867.
JAMES NORTH (20)
, Rape on
Elizabeth Batten.

GUILTY .—
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

868.
MARIA ROWE (22) and
JAMES ROWE (23)
, Unlawfully en
deavouring to conceal the birth of a child, to which

JAMES ROWE
PLEADED GUILTY .—
Five Days' Imprisonment. No evidence was offend against the female prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

869.
JOHN HICKS (41)
, Unlawfully obtaining 7l. 10s. by false pretences.

p.hi: for the Prosecution offered no evidence.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

870.
WILLIAM BRAGG (33)
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully obtaining money by false pretences from
Francis Aggas and others.

871.
ALFRED SMALL (19)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MR. GILL, Prosecuted.

WILLIAM MORGAN . My father is a grocer, of 67, Cornhill Road, Lambeth—on 31st July, about 3 p.m., I served the prisoner with a penny bottle of ginger-beer—he gave me a florin, I gave him 1s. 11d. change—he drank it and went out—I put the florin in the till; there were no others there—a few minutes afterwards he came in again for a pennyworth of cake, and gave me another florin—I put it in the till and gave him 1s. 11d. change, and he went away—I afterwards showed the two florins to my mother and took them to the baker's shop opposite to test them, and gave them back to my mother—about a week afterwards I saw the prisoner by the coke ovens—I Had known him before, and knew where be used to live—I am sure he is the man.
MARY MORGAN . I am the wife of John Morgan—on 31st July my son brought me a florin, and I went into the shop and found another florin in the till—I found they were bad, and gave them to a policeman.

THOMAS GOODMAN (L 85), On 5th August, about 10 o'clock, William Morgan pointed the prisoner out to me, and I took him in custody—I had received the florins before—he asked me the charge—I told him—he said "Oh, it must be a mistake; do you think I am b——silly"—I found no money on him.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These florins are bad and from the same mould.

GUILTY .—He further
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction for felony in July, 1878.—
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

872.
FRANK NORTON, Unlawfully
uttering counterfeit coin.
MR. GILL Prosecuted; MR. S. WHITE Defended.
ELEANOR HILL . I serve at the post-office, Gipsy Eill—the prisoner came

there one afternoon in July for four shillings' worth of stamps, and put dowi a florin and some other coins—I found the florin was had and passed it to the manager, who spoke to the prisoner and gave it hack to him, and he gave me good money and took the stamps away—I am sure he is the man I picked him out from a great many.
Cross-examined. This was at the end of July, hut I don't rememher the date.

FREDERICK PRICE . I manage the post-office, Lower Norwood—in July last Hill handed me a had florin and asked me in the prisoner's presence whether it was bad—I asked him where he got it—he said that he must have got it by accident—he gave me good money, and I sent somebody to follow him—I described him to Inspector Glover next day, and afterwards picked him out from 10 or 12 others.

Cross-examined. I recognised him by his personal appearance and his clothes—the other men were of different ages and wore different kinds of suite, some with whiskers and some without—I slightly bent the coin and gave it back to the prisoner.

FLORENCE HILL . I am employed at the post-office, Lower Norwood—on 11th August the prisoner came in for five shillings' worth of stamps, and gave me two florins, a sixpence, and some coppers—I gave him back one of the florins and said that it was bad—he gave me a good half-crown, I gave him sixpence change, and he left—I spoke to Mr. Corney—I saw the prisoner in custody at the station the same evening.

JONATHAN CORNET . I am assistant to Roland Ellis, of Norwood—no 11th August, a little after 4 o'clock, the prisoner came in for 5s. worth of stamps—Hill spoke to me as he left, and I went out and spoke to Sergeant Lather, and he was taken in custody.
Cross-examined. I gave him in charge at that moment—he did not run away.

ELLEN WALLACE . I live at the Bricklayers' Arms, Lower Norwood—on 11th August the prisoner tendered a florin for a glass of ale—I took it to my mother, and went back and told him it was bad—he gave me a half-crown, I gave him the change, and he left—I picked him out on 13th August from 12 other people by his appearance.
CHARLOTTE WALLACE . My husband keeps the Bricklayers' Anns, Lower Norwood—my daughter brought me a florin on this afternoon—I bent it easily.

JAMES GLOVER (Police Inspector P). On 11th August, about 4.15, the, prisoner was pointed out to me—I followed him about a mile—I was in uniform—I said that he was the young man I wanted—he said, "What fort"—I said, "For uttering a counterfeit two-shilling piece in the post-office in High Street"—he said, "Yes, I was there, and gave the young lady a two-shilling piece, which was bad, but I did not know it was bad"—I asked him where it was, he said that he bent it and threw it away—I asked him where he lived—he said, "In London"—I said, "It is strange you should come here to buy postage stamps"—he said that he thought they would be easier to take home than the money—I found on him a 6d., 5s. worth of stamps, and some bronze—he said that he was going to send the stamps home—he gave his address, 74, Shepherdess Road, Wandsworth—I went there and there was no 74.
Cross-examined. Corney pointed him out—no coins were found on him.

GUILTY —
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

873.
GEORGE WILLIAMS (42),
JOHN JONES (24), and
GEORGE KITSON (38)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Joseph George Stotten, with intent to steal.

WILLIAMS and JONES
PLEADED GUILTY .
MR. GEOGHEGAN Prosecuted: MR. Purcell Defended Kitson; and MR. POYNTER Defended Jones.

MATTHEW FOX (Police Inspector M). On Sunday night, 3rd August, I was in company with Walsh, Harvey, and Stretton, in Old Kent Road, and at 11.30—I then saw Williams and Jones—I saw them again in about half an hour, sitting on the railings in front of a house in the Old Kent Road—Harvey gave me some information at 2 o'clock, in consequence of which I went to the Duke of Kent public-house, in the Old Kent Road, with Harvey, Stretton, and Walsh—I placed a man at each door, and tried to rouse the proprietor, who leaned out of the window and spoke to me—while watching the house, the door was thrown open suddenly, and Jones and Williams attempted to rush out—I secured them, and left them in custody—I then went into the house, and found that an entrance had been effected through the fanlight—I did not see Kitson.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. The last time I saw Kitson he was about 200 yards from the house—it was a fine night, no rain.
JOSEPH GEORGE STOTTEN . I am landlord of the Duke of Kent—I was aroused by the police—I cannot swear to having seen Kitson in the house before, I have seen the other two frequently.

GEORGE HARVEY (Police Sergeant M). I was in company with Walsh, and Fox in the London Road, on the night in question—I saw the three prisoners together about 9.30—I followed them to the Duke of Kent, and about 11.15 they went in at the corner door; the house was then open—in about 10 minutes or a quarter of an hour they came out and went to another public-house, where they remained till closing time, 11—they then came out and separated—I saw them again about 12 at a coffee stall, nearly opposite the Duke of Kent—I saw them again four or five times before 2 o'clock altogether; at one time the three were standing together—I went up Trafalgar Road, and saw a light flash inside the public-house—I was standing opposite, Kitson came across, looked into my face, and passed on—I passed a word to Fox, and he placed us round the house—I took Williams—we took Kitson; he gave us an address.

JAMES WALSH (Police Inspector). I was in company with Fox and Harvey on this night, about 9.30, in the London Road—I saw the prisoners together at 2 on the morning of the 4th outside the Duke of Kent—I saw Kitson coming from the Duke of Kent; I followed him twenty or thirty yards; he turned and looked at me; I walked on to get up to him; he walked quickly and then ran, and I after him for a considerable distance; he got into a hansom—I then turned back and assisted in taking the others—after that I was looking for Kitson,. and found him outside the Crown public-house—I took him to the station and charged him with the burglary—he said "If I knew what it was you wanted me for you should have brought me in pieces."
Cross-examined by MR. PUROELL. The Crown is a mile and a half from the Duke of Kent.

KITSON—
GUILTY .

JONES and KITSON also PLEADED GUILTY to previous convictions.—
Seven Years' Penal Servitude each.
WILLIAMS—
Eighteen Months' Imprisonment.

874.
JAMES WALTER BROWN (40)
, Feloniously forging and uttering an order for 3l. 10s., with intend to defraud.
MR. GEOGHEGAN Prosecuted; MR. FULTON Defended.

RICHARD COXHEAD . I am a zinc-worker, of 73, Jamaica Road—on 24th May the prisoner came and asked me to cash a cheque for 3l. 10s.—he said somebody at Islington had given it to him—I told him I had not the money—I took it to Mr. Evans, a neighbour, and got it cashed—Mr. Evans sent it to Mr. Johnson, and it was returned four days afterwards marked "No account.

Cross-examined. I have known the prisoner some little time, and have cashed cheques for him before, one for 25l.—this cheque purports to be drawn by a man named Jay—the prisoner wrote his name on the back; I did not ask him to do so—I have no banker.
Re-examined. The prisoner said "The party I had it from is all right, and he has had a banking account for some years.

GEORGE ALBERT HILDT . I am manager to Mr. Wilkinson, of the Surrey Canal Saw Mills—I have received letters from the prisoner and have seen him afterwards and referred to them—I am acquainted with his hand
writing—I believe the signature "William Jay" to this cheque to be his writing.
Cross-examined. I said so at the police-court when he was charged by Mr. Wilkinson with obtaining money by false pretences upon this cheque; he was admitted to bail.
Re-examined. He brought me a bill for 20l. 10s., which was dishonoured.

FREDERICK DEAKIN . I received this letter (produced) from the prisoner—he told me that he had written it himself; I did not see him write it—I believe all those three documents to be in his handwriting—I gave them all to Mr. Chabot—I was at the police-court on all the occasions—no charge of forgery was definitely preferred till the last occasion, after the cheque was shown to Mr. Chabot—I had mislaid it.

Cross-examined. The prisoner was committed for trial for false pretences and admitted to bail after opposition by me—I did not know that I could prefer a bill without the permission of the Magistrate—I have no ill
feeling against the prisoner.
Re-examined. I opposed his going out on bail purely in my professional capacity as a solicitor.

CHARLES CHABOT . I am an expert in handwriting—I have compared all the documents produced, and some others with this cheque—to the best of my belief the whole of the writing on the front of the cheque except the words "No account" is in the same handwriting as these documents—it is an assumed hand, not in the prisoner's natural handwriting—the endorse
ment "J. W. Brown" is in his natural handwriting.
Cross-examined. My evidence is based on my past experience—it has been occasionally differed from—Mr. Nethercliff had been opposed to me about seven or eight times.

CHARLES EDWIN SCARISBROOK . I am a clerk at the Holborn Branch of the Union Bank of London—this yellow cheque was issued in a book of 100 cheques to a customer of the bank, Mr. C. J. Moger, on 22nd January, 1877—the last transaction they had with us was nine or ten months ago—they have presented no cheque since—we have no customer named Jay.
RICHARD KIMBER (Detective). I took the prisoner into custody on 30th

August—I read the warrant to him—he said, "I know nothing about it"—after he was liberated on bail I arrested him on the charge of forgery—he said, "I have been discharged for that"—I said, "No, the cheque was mislaid, and we did not go into the charge of forgery."
Cross-examined. There were two charges before the Magistrate, one for false pretences, which was dismissed, and the other was with reference to this cheque.

GUILTY .—
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

875.
GEORGE WEBB (25)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Lawton Haddon, with intent to steal.

JOHN HADDON . I am a civil engineer, at 21, Lansdowne Road, Clapham—on 17th August, about 9.30,1 retired to bed, leaving some of my family up; and about 3 am. my wife woke me—I saw the outline of the prisoner standing at the foot of the bed—I caught him by the throat before he had time to move—his hands were on the mantelpiece, within a foot of my watch and ring—we have since missed a silver top of a cruet from the room he entered—I asked him how he got in; and he said, "Through the window; it was open"—I examined the premises and found foot-marks leading to the window—it looks out on to a veranda.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. We had not found out the loss of the cruet top when before the Magistrates.
ELLEN HORSFOLD . I am servant to Mr. Haddon—I saw the windows closed about 9.45, and was the last person up.

GEORGE HAZEL (Police Sergeant W 18). I examined the premises at 21, Lansdowe Road, and found foot-marks of two different persons in the back garden, and traced them to the balcony and found mud on the window curtains.
PETER BERRY (Policeman W 369). I took the prisoner in custody at the door of the house, and searched him but found nothing on him.

GUILTY . He also PLEADED GUILTY to having been before convicted of felony at this Court.—
Five years' Penal Servitude.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, OCTOBER 20TH, 1879.
